solution:
From the double angle formula,
\[\cos \left( 2 \theta + \frac{\pi}{2} \right) = 1 - 2 \sin^2 \left( \theta + \frac{\pi}{4} \right) = 1 - 2 \left( \frac{1}{3} \right)^2 = \frac{7}{9}.\]But $\cos \left( 2 \theta + \frac{\pi}{2} \right) = -\sin 2 \theta,$ so $\sin 2 \theta = \boxed{-\frac{7}{9}}.$
gptanswer:
We have that $\sin \left( \theta + \frac{\pi}{4} \right) = \frac{1}{3},$ so
\[\sin \left( \theta + \frac{\pi}{4} \right) - \sin \theta = \frac{1}{3} - \frac{1}{3} = \frac{2}{3}.\]Then,
\[\sin 2 \theta = \frac{\sin \theta \cdot \theta}{2} = \frac{\sin \theta}{2} \cdot \frac{\theta}{2} = \frac{\sin \theta}{2}.\]We can also use the fact that $\sin \theta = 1/2 \cdot \cos \theta,$ so
\[\sin 2 \theta = \frac{\sin \theta}{2} = \frac{1/2 \cdot \cos \theta}{2} = \frac{1/4 \cdot \cos \theta}{2} = \frac{1/4 \cdot \cos \theta}{2} = \frac{\cos \theta}{2}.\]Then,
\[\cos 2 \theta = 1 - \frac{\cos 2 \theta}{2} = 1 - \frac{\cos \theta}{2} = \boxed{\frac{1 - \sin \theta}{2}}.\]
